title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond. P represents the bond price

title: Zero-Coupon Bond Price (Continuous)
equation_latex: P = F * e^{-y \times T}
notes: This equation calculates the price of a zero-coupon bond using continuous compounding. P represents the bond price

title: Coupon Bond Price
notes: This equation calculates the price of a coupon bond. P represents the bond price

title: Coupon Bond Price (Annual)
notes: This equation calculates the price of an annual coupon bond using the annuity formula. P represents the bond price

title: Coupon Bond Price (Semi-Annual)
equation_latex: P = C/y/2 * (1 - 1/(1 + y/2)^{2 \t \times im \times es \times n}) + F/(1 + y/2)^{2 \t \times im \times es \times n}
notes: This equation calculates the price of a semi-annual coupon bond. P represents the bond price

title: Bond Price Between Coupon Dates
notes: This equation calculates the bond price between coupon dates

title: Accrued Interest
equation_latex: __A \times BB \times R0__ = C * (D \times ay \times s s \times in \times ce \times la \times st \times co \times up \times on / D \times ay \times s i \times n c \times ou \times po \times n p \times er \times io \times d)
notes: This equation calculates the accrued interest on a bond between coupon dates. AI represents the accrued interest

title: Dirty Price
equation_latex: D \times P = C \times le \times an \times Pr \times ic \times e + A \times cc \times ru \times ed \times In \times te \times re \times st
notes: This equation expresses the relationship between dirty price and clean price. DP represents the dirty price (full price)

title: Yield to Maturity (Zero-Coupon)
notes: This equation calculates the yield to maturity for a zero-coupon bond. y represents the yield to maturity as a decimal

title: Yield to Maturity (Coupon Bond)
notes: This equation defines the yield to maturity for a coupon bond. y represents the yield to maturity that equates the present value of all cash flows to the current price P. The YTM for coupon bonds must be solved numerically (e.g.

title: Current Yield
equation_latex: __A \times BB \times R0__ = C / P
notes: This equation calculates the current yield of a bond. CY represents the current yield

title: Yield to Call (First Call)
equation_latex: P = s \times um_{t=1}^{n_{c}} C/(1 + y_{t \times c})^{t} + F_{c}/(1 + y_{t \times c})^{n_{c}}
notes: This equation calculates the yield to call for a callable bond. y_{tc} represents the yield to call

title: Yield to Worst
equation_latex: __A \times BB \times R1__ = m \times in \t \times im \times es (__A \times BB \times R0__
notes: YTC_2

title: Zero-Coupon Yield Curve
equation_latex: r_{t} = -l \times n \t \times im \times es (P_{t}) / t
notes: This equation extracts the zero-coupon yield curve from zero-coupon bond prices. r_t represents the continuously compounded zero rate for maturity t

title: Par Yield
equation_latex: y_{p \times ar} = (1 - P_{T}) / (s \times um_{t=1}^{T} P_{t})
notes: This equation calculates the par yield from zero-coupon discount factors. y_par represents the par yield (coupon rate that prices the bond at par)

title: Forward Rate from Spot Rates
equation_latex: F_{t
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Forward Rate (Continuous)
equation_latex: F_{t
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Instantaneous Forward Rate
equation_latex: f \t \times im \times es (t) = r \t \times im \times es (t) + t * d \times r \t \times im \times es (t)/d \times t
notes: This equation defines the instantaneous forward rate. f(t) represents the instantaneous forward rate for time t

title: Spot Rate from Forward Rates
notes: Fixed Income - Yield Curve Analysis

title: Nelson-Siegel Yield Curve
equation_latex: y \t \times im \times es (t) = b \times et \times a_{0} + b \times et \times a_{1} * (1 - e^{-t/t \times au})/(t/t \times au) + b \times et \times a_{2} * ((1 - e^{-t/t \times au})/(t/t \times au) - e^{-t/t \times au})
notes: This is the Nelson-Siegel parameterization of the yield curve. y(t) represents the yield at time t

title: Nelson-Siegel-Svensson Extension
equation_latex: y \t \times im \times es (t) = b \times et \times a_{0} + b \times et \times a_{1} * (1 - e^{-t/t \times au_{1}})/(t/t \times au_{1}) + b \times et \times a_{2} * ((1 - e^{-t/t \times au_{1}})/(t/t \times au_{1}) - e^{-t/t \times au_{1}}) + b \times et \times a_{3} * ((1 - e^{-t/t \times au_{2}})/(t/t \times au_{2}) - e^{-t/t \times au_{2}})
notes: This is the Nelson-Siegel-Svensson extension with an additional hump term. y(t) represents the yield at time t

title: Yield Curve Steepness
equation_latex: S \times lo \times pe = y_{10 \t \times im \times es \times y} - y_{2 \t \times im \times es \times y}
notes: This equation measures the steepness of the yield curve. Slope represents the difference between the 10-year yield and the 2-year yield. A positive slope indicates an upward-sloping yield curve (normal)

title: Yield Curve Curvature
equation_latex: C \times ur \times va \times tu \times re = 2 * y_{10 \t \times im \times es \times y} - y_{2 \t \times im \times es \times y} - y_{30 \t \times im \times es \times y}
notes: This equation measures the curvature (hump) of the yield curve. Curvature captures the non-linearity of the yield curve shape. A positive curvature indicates a hump-shaped yield curve

title: Butterfly Spread
equation_latex: B \times ut \times te \times rf \times ly = y_{10 \t \times im \times es \times y} - (y_{2 \t \times im \times es \times y} + y_{30 \t \times im \times es \times y})/2
notes: This equation calculates the butterfly spread of the yield curve. Butterfly measures the deviation of the intermediate yield from the average of the short and long yields. It's a key measure for yield curve strategies and relative value analysis.

title: Macaulay Duration
equation_latex: D_{m \times ac} = s \times um_{t=1}^{n} (t * C \times F_{t} / (1 + y)^{t}) / P
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a bond. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Macaulay Duration (Zero-Coupon)
equation_latex: D_{m \times ac} = T
notes: This equation shows that the Macaulay duration of a zero-coupon bond equals its time to maturity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Macaulay Duration (Perpetuity)
equation_latex: D_{m \times ac} = (1 + y) / y
notes: This equation calculates the Macaulay duration of a perpetuity. D_mac represents the Macaulay duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Modified Duration
equation_latex: D_{m \times od} = D_{m \times ac} / (1 + y)
notes: This equation calculates the modified duration from Macaulay duration. D_mod represents the modified duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Modified Duration (Approximation)
equation_latex: D_{m \times od} ≈ -(P_- - P_+) / (2 * P * d \times y)
notes: This equation approximates modified duration using finite differences. D_mod represents the modified duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Dollar Duration
equation_latex: D \times D = -D_{m \times od} * P
notes: This equation calculates the dollar duration (also called PV01 or DV01). DD represents the dollar duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Price Value of a Basis Point
equation_latex: P \times V01 = -(P \t \times im \times es (y + 0.0001) - P \t \times im \times es (y - 0.0001)) / 2
notes: This equation calculates the price value of a basis point (PV01). PV01 represents the price change for a 1 basis point (0.01%) change in yield. PV01 is a standard risk measure used in fixed income markets and is equivalent to dollar duration scaled by 0.0001.

title: Effective Duration
equation_latex: D_{e \times ff} = -(P_- - P_+) / (2 * P * d \times y)
notes: This equation calculates the effective duration for bonds with embedded options. D_eff represents the effective duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Key Rate Duration
equation_latex: K \times RD_{i} = -(P \t \times im \times es (y + d \times y_{i}) - P \t \times im \times es (y - d \times y_{i})) / (2 * P * d \times y_{i})
notes: This equation calculates the key rate duration for a specific key rate. KRD_i represents the key rate duration for key rate i Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Convexity
equation_latex: C \times on \times v = s \times um_{t=1}^{n} (t \t \times im \times es (t+1) * C \times F_{t} / (1 + y)^{t+2}) / P
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond. Conv represents convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships.

title: Convexity (Zero-Coupon)
equation_latex: C \times on \times v = T \t \times im \times es (T+1) / (1 + y)^{2}
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a zero-coupon bond. Conv represents the convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships.

title: Convexity (Perpetuity)
equation_latex: C \times on \times v = 2(1 + y) / y^{2}
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a perpetuity. Conv represents the convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships.

title: Effective Convexity
equation_latex: C \times on \times v_{e \times ff} = (P_+ + P_- - 2 \t \times im \times es \times P) / (P * d \times y^{2})
notes: This equation calculates the effective convexity for bonds with embedded options. Conv_eff represents the effective convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships.

title: Dollar Convexity
equation_latex: D \times C = C \times on \times v * P
notes: This equation calculates the dollar convexity. DC represents the dollar convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships.

title: Price Change Approximation
equation_latex: d \times P/P ≈ -D_{m \times od} * d \times y + 0.5 * C \times on \times v * (d \times y)^{2}
notes: This equation approximates the percentage price change of a bond for a small change in yield. dP/P represents the percentage price change

title: Taylor Series Expansion
equation_latex: P \t \times im \times es (y + d \times y) ≈ P \t \times im \times es (y) + P'(y)d \times y + 0.5 \t \times im \times es \times P''(y)(d \times y)^{2}
notes: This is the Taylor series expansion of bond price with respect to yield. P(y + dy) is the new price

title: Bond Portfolio Duration
equation_latex: D_{p \times or \times t} = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} * D_{i}
notes: This equation calculates the duration of a bond portfolio. D_port represents the portfolio duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Bond Portfolio Convexity
equation_latex: C \times on \times v_{p \times or \times t} = s \times um_{i=1}^{n} w_{i} * C \times on \times v_{i}
notes: This equation calculates the convexity of a bond portfolio. Conv_port represents the portfolio convexity Convexity captures the second-order effect in price-yield relationships.

title: Immunization Condition 1
notes: This is the first immunization condition for matching asset and liability durations. D_A represents the duration of assets

title: Immunization Condition 2
equation_latex: C \times on \times v_{A} > C \times on \times v_{L}
notes: This is the second immunization condition. Conv_A represents the convexity of assets

title: Reinvestment Risk
equation_latex: R_{r \times ei \times nv} = s \times um_{t=1}^{n} C \times F_{t} * ((1 + y_{r})^{n-t} - (1 + y)^{n-t})
notes: This equation calculates the reinvestment risk of a bond. R_reinv represents the reinvestment risk

title: Price Risk
equation_latex: R_{p \times ri \times ce} = P \t \times im \times es (y + d \times y) - P \t \times im \times es (y)
notes: This equation calculates the price risk of a bond. R_price represents the price risk

title: Total Bond Risk
equation_latex: R_{t \times ot \times al} = R_{p \times ri \times ce} + R_{r \times ei \times nv}
notes: This equation calculates the total bond risk. R_total represents the total risk

title: Spread Duration
equation_latex: D_{s \times pr \times ea \times d} = -(P \t \times im \times es (y + d \times y + d \times s) - P \t \times im \times es (y + d \times y - d \times s)) / (2 * P * d \times s)
notes: This equation calculates the spread duration Duration is the primary measure of interest rate sensitivity in fixed income.

title: Yield Beta
equation_latex: b \times et \times a = (d \times P_{b \times on \times d} / P_{b \times on \times d}) / (d \times P_{b \times en \times ch \times ma \times rk} / P_{b \times en \times ch \times ma \times rk})
notes: This equation calculates the yield beta of a bond relative to a benchmark. beta represents the yield beta

title: Tracking Error
equation_latex: T \times E = s \times qr \times t \t \times im \times es ((1/T) * s \times um_{t=1}^{T} (R_{p \times or \times tf \times ol \times io}

title: Information Ratio
equation_latex: __A \times BB \times R0__ = (R_{p \times or \times tf \times ol \times io} - R_{b \times en \times ch \times ma \times rk}) / T \times E
notes: This equation calculates the information ratio of a bond portfolio. IR represents the information ratio
